skill.name: apktool
skill.description: Android APK unpacking and resource extraction tool for reverse engineering. Use when you need to decode APK files, extract resources, examine AndroidManifest.xml, analyze smali code, or repackage modified APKs.

skill.author: BrownFineSecurity

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only instructional content for using apktool. No executable code, no file system access, no network calls, no external command execution. The skill provides guidance for legitimate reverse engineering tasks including security analysis and vulnerability discovery.

content.value_statement: Need to analyze Android applications for security vulnerabilities or extract app resources. This skill provides step-by-step guidance for unpacking APK files, examining manifests, and analyzing smali code using apktool.
actual_capabilities: Unpack and decode APK files to readable resources
Extract and analyze AndroidManifest.xml for permissions and components
Search for hardcoded credentials, API keys, and URLs in app resources
Disassemble DEX bytecode to smali code for code analysis
Examine native libraries and their architectures
Repackage modified APKs with proper signing procedures
limitations: Requires apktool and Java Runtime Environment installed on the system
Cannot decompile to Java source (use jadx for Java decompilation)
Obfuscated apps may have unreadable class and method names
Does not provide built-in output formatting for analysis results

use_cases.title: Vulnerability Assessment
use_cases.description: Analyze Android apps for security misconfigurations, exported components, and hardcoded secrets.

use_cases.title: IoT App Inspection
use_cases.description: Extract API endpoints and credentials from companion apps to understand device communication protocols.

use_cases.title: Authorized Penetration Testing
use_cases.description: Support authorized security testing by unpacking APKs and documenting app internals.

prompt_templates.title: Basic APK Unpack
prompt_templates.prompt: Unpack the APK file at [PATH] using apktool and output to [DIRECTORY]. Show the directory structure after extraction.

prompt_templates.title: Manifest Security Scan
prompt_templates.prompt: After unpacking [APK], examine the AndroidManifest.xml. List all permissions, exported components, and check for debuggable flag and allowBackup setting.

prompt_templates.title: Credential Hunt
prompt_templates.prompt: Search the unpacked APK at [DIRECTORY] for hardcoded API keys, passwords, tokens, and secrets. Show the file paths and context for each finding.

prompt_templates.title: Full Security Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform a complete security analysis of [APK]. Unpack it, examine the manifest, search for credentials and URLs in resources, and check exported components. Summarize findings.

output_examples.input: Unpack the target.apk file and analyze it for security issues
output: Security Notes: android:allowBackup=true may expose user data

best_practices: Always work on copies of APK files, never originals, to preserve evidence integrity
Examine the AndroidManifest.xml first before diving into code or resources
Document all findings including package names, versions, permissions, and discovered credentials
anti_patterns: Running apktool without specifying an output directory can create messy files
Analyzing APKs without permission violates ethical guidelines and may be illegal
Skipping manifest analysis misses critical security information like exported components

faq.question: Does apktool require installation?
faq.answer: Yes, apktool must be installed separately. It requires Java Runtime Environment (JRE) to run.

faq.question: Can apktool convert APK to Java source?
faq.answer: No, apktool produces smali code. Use jadx for Java decompilation with readable source code.

faq.question: What APK protections does apktool bypass?
faq.answer: Apktool handles standard Android packaging. Some obfuscation and packing tools may require additional techniques.

faq.question: Is credential extraction ethical?
faq.answer: Only extract credentials from apps you own or have explicit authorization to analyze. Respect intellectual property.

faq.question: Why do some resources fail to decode?
faq.answer: Some apps use custom obfuscation or framework-dependent resources. Try the --keep-broken-res flag to preserve what can be decoded.

faq.question: How does this compare to jadx?
faq.answer: Apktool is faster for manifest and resource extraction. Jadx provides readable Java source but requires more memory and processing time.
